R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Aldol condensation of the syngas-methanol derivatives is an important renewable route for acrylic acid production and coal clean-efficient utilization. In this work, a series of mesoporous alkaline earth metal (x) oxide-modified VPxO/SiO2 catalysts were designed and prepared for gas-aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to acrylic acid. The doping of alkaline earth metal oxide into VPO/SiO2 effectively promoted the dispersion and exposure of the VPO species and adjusted the amount of surface (VO)2P2O7/γ-VOPO4 (V4+/V5+). Especially, the SrO and BaO obviously altered the surface chemical environment of VPO species and the strength of acid-base sites, exhibiting strong interaction with both (VO)2P2O7 and γ-VOPO4. The formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity over the VPxO/SiO2 increased with about 5.0–10.0 % and 8.0–16.0 % comparing with the VPO/SiO2, respectively. By optimizing the doping amount of BaO and reaction temperature, the VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst achieved a formaldehyde conversion of 70.4 % and an acrylic acid yield of approximately 65.5 % (with formation rate of 12.5 mmol gcat −1 h−1). The VPxO/SiO2 catalysts also showed slightly improved catalytic stability than the VPO/SiO2. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Catalytic aldol condensation Formaldehyde Acrylic acid Vanadium phosphorus oxide Alkaline metal oxides Data Availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Acrylic acid (AA) is the smallest molecule having both CC double bond and carboxyl group, which become an important chemical intermediate and multifunctional polymer monomer to produce acrylate esters (such as methyl ester, ethyl ester, butyl ester, and isooctyl ester), superabsorbent polymers and assisting washing agents [1,2]. These downstream chemicals have been widely used as adhesives, coatings, superabsorbent materials, polishing agents, and so on, in the fields of textile fiber, medical health, construction industry and petrochemical industry [3,4]. The global consumption of acrylic acid now reached 6.5 million tons/year, mainly based on petroleum-route though two-step oxidation of propylene via acrolein intermediate [5–10]. However, the global environmental issues and volatility of global oil market raised a strong motivation to develop alternative and renewable routes for acrylic acid industrial production, such as the syngas-methanol and biomass-glycerol (or glucose and starch) routes [11–16]. During the past years, one-step aldol condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde to acrylic acid has received particular attention and been considered as one of the most promising syngas-methanol approaches to achieve the industrial production, due to the few reaction steps, high atomic economy, low cost of raw materials (particularly overproduction capacity of acetic acid) [18–21]. Different kinds of catalysts, such as basic oxide (Cs/SiO2, Cs/Al2O3), acidic oxides (HZSM-5), or VPO oxides ((VO)2P2O7, VOPO4) with both acid and base sites, have been found to show high catalytic activity for this hydroxyl aldehyde condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to form a new CC bond (carbon chain growth) [22–24]. It is commonly accepted that acrylic acid produced through formaldehyde carbocation intermediate and enol intermediate formed over the acid sites from formaldehyde and acetic acid, respectively. The subsequent steps involve continuous addition and dehydration reactions, with the activation of acetic acid on the surface acid sites being a crucial step in the overall reaction process [25,26]. Over the basic oxide catalysts, acetic acid is activated on the surface basic sites to form a carbon anion, and followed reacting with formaldehyde to form acrylic acid, and the basic sites has higher ability to activate acetic acid than the acidic sites [27–29]. Moreover, the studies revealed that synergistic activation of the surface acid-base sites for respective activation of formaldehyde and acetic acid was more effective to produce acrylic acid [30–33]. The current challenge for this reaction is the design and preparation of effective catalysts with high catalytic activity and stability for resistance of carbon-deposition. According to the previous studies, the ZSM-5 zeolite (having unique pore structure, strong surface acidity and water resistance) showed high catalytic performance for the condensation reaction of hydroxyl aldehyde, and yielded methyl acrylate (MA) about 42 % from selectivity about 99 % of methyl acetate/formaldehyde (molar ratio of 5) after 9 wt% P modified in the ZSM-5 [34–36]. The yield of methyl acrylate over the P modified ZSM-5 decreased from 42 % to less than 20 % within initial 30 h, which can be recovered as the catalyst being calcined at 400 °C for 24 h [34]. The catalytic condensation of methyl acetate and methylal can undergo over the HZSM-35, with methyl acetate conversion up to 61 % and total selectivity of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate reaching 82 %, respectively [35,36]. The catalyst deactivation is very fast with the color quickly turning black, because of the narrow pore channel of molecular sieve was conducive to formation of carbon deposition (about 10 wt%) [36,37]. It was reported a formaldehyde conversion can reached 50∼60 % with acrylic acid selectivity of 80∼100 % from condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde (high molar ratio of 10/1) over alkaline metal-Declaso catalysts [25]. For the silica gel supported alkali metals (Na, K, Rb, Cs or Ba), RbOH/SiO2 had formaldehyde conversion about 48 % with acrylic selectivity of about 94 %[34]. The alkaline catalysts also deactivated fast within initial 3–4 h, and the yield of methyl acrylate is reduced by half. The VPO-based oxides, another typical kind of catalyst, was first reported in 1987 to yield acrylic acid of about 75 % from formalin and acetic acid reaction system, in which acetone and CO2 were the main byproducts [19]. It had confirmed the presence of P in the catalyst was beneficial to reduce the alkalinity of the catalyst, thus inhibiting the decomposition of acetic acid or acrylic acid. Driven by this, VPO-based catalysts were developed, such as using pore-forming agent of PEG6000 (treated in an oxidizing atmosphere containing butane) and mesoporous SiO2 (or ordered mesoporous SBA-15), and confirmed a mixture of (VO)2P2O7 and δ-VOPO4 being the active phases [38–41]. The catalytic activity of VPO active phase followed the order of VOPO4 > VOPO4·2 H2O > highly disordered (VO)2P2O7 > relatively ordered (VO)2P2O7, and pure crystalline (VO)2P2O7 or excessive crystalline δ-VOPO4 phases showed low catalytic activity [38]. The further designed VPO-based oxide catalysts containing both crystalline δ-VOPO4 and γ-VOPO4 (w/w, 3/1) showed the total yield of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate can reach 84 % after optimizing the reaction conditions [42,43]. The factors that influence the catalytic performance of VPO-based oxide catalysts are interconnected and cannot be isolated from one another. For instance, the structure, phase composition, molar ratio of P/V, and relative content of V4+/V5+ all impact the strength, quantity, and distribution of acid-base sites, ultimately leading to varying degrees of synergistic activation of these sites [38–45]. A low-cost and effective approach on this was modification of metal oxides (ZrO, NbOx, CeO2) in VPO species, resulting in an increase on the yield of target products [46–49]. However, more efforts need to be put on these catalysts before industrialization. In this study, a series of commercial mesoporous SiO2 supported alkaline earth metal oxide (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba) modified VPO-based oxide catalysts were thus designed and prepared to improve acrylic acid yield from gas aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid, based on previous research works [39,40,44–46]. The prepared solid acid catalysts were characterized by various techniques such as BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller), XRD (X-ray diffraction), Raman, XPS (X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy), TEM-EDS (Transmission electron microscopy equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy), NH3-TPD (NH3 temperature-programmed desorption), CO2-TPD (CO2 temperature-programmed desorption), and TG (Thermo-gravimetric), to reveal the relationship of the catalytic performance with physicochemical properties of catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation In a typical synthesis of commercial mesoporous SiO2 supported VPO-based oxides by simple wet impregnation method, 2.5 g ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) was dissolved in 45 mL deionized water, followed by adding 5.5 g oxalic acid (H2C2O4), 4.9 g phosphoric acid (85 %) (Vanadium phosphorus molar ratio nV/nP of 0.5), 0.83 mL hydrochloric acid (37 wt%), and corresponding alkaline metal nitrate precursor (Mg(NO3)2∙6 H2O, Ca(NO3)2∙4 H2O, Sr(NO3)2 or Ba(NO3)2) with molar ratio nx/nv of 0.15 (x = Mg, Ca, Sr, or Ba, the mass loading of BaO was just 1.0 wt% of catalyst). The water bath was kept at 60 °C and stirred for 30 min, and then a corresponding amount of SiO2 (the total mass loading of V2O5 and P2O5 was 20.0 wt%) was added, and followed stirring for another 4 h at 60 °C until the water being evaporated. Through drying 100 °C for 24 h, the sample was calcinated at 400 °C for 4 h. Finally, the catalyst was obtained and designated as VPO/SiO2 and VPxO/SiO2 (x = Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba). The VPO-based oxide samples with different amount of the Ba precursor (nBa/nv = 0.07 and 0.23, with mass loading of BaO being 0.5 wt% and 1.5 wt%, respectively) were also prepared by the same method, and designated as VPBaO-0.07/SiO2 and VPBaO-0.23/SiO2, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 N2 physisorption Adsorption and desorption isotherms were collected on Nova 2200e at –196 °C. Prior to the measurement, all samples were degassed at 200 °C until a stable vacuum of ca. 5 m Torr was reached. The specific surface area was assessed using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method from adsorption data in a relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.30. The total pore volume, V t , was assessed from the adsorbed amount of nitrogen at a relative pressure of 0.95 by converting it to the corresponding volume of liquid adsorbate. d 0 is the average pore diameter calculated from the desorption branch of the isotherm using the BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) method. 2.2.2 XRD characterization X–ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Fangyuan DX-1000 powder X-ray diffractometer (China) with Cu Kα radiation at a tube voltage of 40 kV, and the data of 2θ were collected from 10° to 70° range with 0.02° of the step size at the rate of 5° min−1. 2.2.3 TEM-EDS analysis Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed using a Tecnai G2 Spirit microscope operating and equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The samples were prepared by ultrasonication in ethanol, evaporating a drop of the resultant suspension onto a carbon–coated copper grid. The chemical composition of the catalysts was determined using natural and synthetic standards and 20 kV accelerating voltage with 10 nA beam current. 2.2.4 XPS analysis The surface chemical states and distribution the catalysts were certified by the X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The signals were collected by a Kratos X–ray source with an aluminium crystal, operating at 12 kV anode voltage and 12 mA emission current, was used to generate the required Al Kα radiation. Curve fitting and background subtraction were performed using Casa XPS software. 2.2.5 Raman analysis The Raman spectra was collected on Renishaw2000 spectrometer (Renishaw company, UK) with Olympus CCD detector, and the excitation wavelength was 532 nm with the test range of 100–1300 cm−1. 2.2.6 NH3-TPD studies NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted using a conventional apparatus equipped with a TCD detector. 100 mg of sample was placed in a quartz tube (4.0 mm ID), and pretreated with at 300 °C for 1 h; as the temperature cooled down to 50 °C, NH3 was chemisorbed until equilibrium was reached. After this, the sample was switched to He gas flow (30 mL/min) for 20 min at 50 °C, and then the TPD was performed by heating the sample at 10 °C·min−1 from 50 °C to 600 °C. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement Catalytic tests of all catalysts were carried out in a continuous flow fixed–bed quartz tubular reactor (i.d. 8 mm) under atmospheric pressure. The quartz tube reactor containing 200 mg of catalysts mixed with 200 mg of quartz (both 380–700 µm) was placed inside a tubular furnace. The carrier gas (N2) was passed downward through the reactor containing the catalyst bed, while electronic mass flow controller (D07–7A/ZM, China) was used to control the flow rate at 30 mL min−1 (GHSV of 3069 h−1). After the temperature of the heating furnace and reactor had reached 390 °C and 350 °C, respectively, a mixed solution of acetic acid and 1,3,5-trioxane (molar ratio AcOH (acetic acid) /1,3,5-trioxane: 9/1) was pumped in at a flow rate of 1 mL h−1 using a syringe pump (LSP01–1A, china). The products were cooled through an ice-water trap and collected in every two hours, and the obtained product selectivity or yield showed the average of each 2 h. The collected liquid samples were analyzed with a HP 5890 Series II gas chromatograph equipped with a HP-Innowax (19091 N-113, 30 m * 0.32 mm * 0.25 mm) and an FID (Flame ionization detector) detector. Pentanoic acid was selected as the internal standard for the quantification of products. In some cases, the unreacted formaldehyde content was analyzed by the Na2SO3 acid-base titration method, to directly determine the formaldehyde conversion. The formaldehyde conversion (C F ) and product selectivity (S AA ,) was calculated from the molar concentrations of product and formaldehyde according to Eq. (1) and Eq. (2), respectively. The yield of products was equal to C F × S AA . (1) C F % = M F , in − M F , out M F , in × 100 (2) S AA ( % ) = M AA M F , in − M F , out × 100 The M F, in and M F, out represent the molar quantity of formaldehyde in and out of the reactor, respectively. M AA represents the detected molar quantity of acrylic acid [28]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 N2 adsorption/desorption characterization The textural parameters of the SiO2 and VPO-based oxide catalysts were characterized by N2 physical adsorption/desorption characterization, and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1. From Fig. 1a, the SiO2 and VPO-based oxide catalysts showed a type IV isotherm with similar H3 hysteresis based on the IUPAC classification and a steep capillary condensation step between P/P0 = 0.65–0.90, which were characteristic of developed mesoporous materials [50,51]. This phenomenon demonstrated that the VPO/SiO2 and VPxO/SiO2 maintained the well-developed mesoporous structure of the SiO2. In other words, the highly specific surface area of the mesoporous SiO2 promoted the dispersion of VPO species. As shown in Fig. 1b, the pore sizes of SiO2 was narrowly distributed between 3.0 nm and 15.0 nm, and the distribution peak centered around 10.0 nm. The VPO-based oxide catalysts showed the pore sizes distributed between 5.0 nm and 13.0 nm with much lower peak intensity comparing with that of the SiO2. Table 1 exhibited the textural data from N2 physical adsorption-desorption isotherm. The average pore diameter d 0 (Table 1) for SiO2, VPO/SiO2, VPMgO/SiO2, VPCaO/SiO2, VPSrO/SiO2 and VPBaO/SiO2 catalysts were 10.3 nm, 10.6 nm, 10.9 nm, 11.1 nm, 11.2 nm, and 11.3 nm, respectively. The slightly increase of d 0 for the samples may be related to the metal radius of alkaline metals or the crystalline VPO composition on SiO2 [39,46]. The VPO/SiO2 and VPxO/SiO2 catalysts have the SBET about 220.0 m2/g and Vt about 0.53–0.65 cm3/g, respectively. This indicated modification of alkaline earth metal oxide on VPO/SiO2 did not cause obvious influence on the SBET and VT of catalysts. 3.2 XRD characterization Fig. 2 showed the crystalline composition of the prepared VPO-based oxide catalysts characterized by the XRD. As shown in Fig. 2(a and b), the VPO/SiO2 and alkane earth metal oxide modified VPxO/SiO2 catalysts exhibited XRD pattern with obvious peaks centered at 2θ of about 12.7°, 22.4°, and 28.9°. The XRD peak at 2θ of about 22.4° was ascribed to the SiO2 with mesoporous structure [50]. The XRD peaks at 2θ of about 12.7° and 28.9° were assigned to the crystalline VOPO4 and (VO)2P2O7, respectively [19,24,33]. Moreover, several weak peaks assigned to P2O5 can be slightly observed at 2θ of about 21.8°, 23.7°, and 26.9°, but which were badly covered by the widen XRD peak of SiO2 [41]. The findings revealed the coexistence of VOPO4 and (VO)2P2O7 (without any obvious crystalline alkaline earth metal oxides or alkaline earth phosphate) on the surface of SiO2, because of the low mass loading or excellent dispersion of the alkaline earth metal oxides (MgO, CaO, SrO, and BaO) on SiO2. The peak intensity of the VPO species was significantly lower than that obtained through precipitation methods, indicating that the vanadium phosphorus oxides (VPO) were well-dispersed on SiO2. This dispersion was facilitated by the well-developed mesoporous structure and high specific surface area of SiO2, as evidenced by the BET results presented in Fig. 1 [16,24,45]. However, the peak intensity of the VPO (VOPO4 and (VO)2P2O7) species increased followed order of VPO/SiO2 < VPMgO/SiO2 < VPCaO/SiO2 < VPSrO/SiO2 < VPBaO/SiO2. And the peak intensity of the (VO)2P2O7 reduced as the increment of the amount (nBa/nv = 0.07 and 0.23) of BaO on VPO/SiO2. These phenomena indicated the modification of alkaline earth metal oxides held prominent influence on the crystalline composition of VPO on SiO2. 3.3 Raman characterization As the VOPO4 has different crystalline phases such as α-VOPO4, β-VOPO4, γ-VOPO4, and δ-VOPO4, the Raman characterization over the prepared samples was carried out to further investigate the difference on the crystalline composition of the VPO-based oxide catalysts, and the results in shown in Fig. 3. It can be observed from Fig. 3 that the prepared VPO-based oxide samples all exhibited well-resolved two Raman bands at about at about 922–925 cm−1 and 1032–1040 cm−1, while the VPO/SiO2, VPMgO/SiO2, VPCaO/SiO2, and VPSrO/SiO2 exhibited additional relatively-weak Raman bands at about 1146 cm−1. According to the previous studies, the Raman band at about 921–925 cm−1 can be attributed to νas P-O-P in the P2O7 4- unit of (VO)2P2O7, and the bands at 1032–1040 cm−1 were characteristic V-O-P stretching of the γ-VOPO4 species [38,42,52–54]. The Raman band located at about 1146–1153 cm−1 may be assigned to γ-VOPO4/αI-VOPO4 species [52,54]. At the same time, it can be clearly observed the shift on the Raman bands (900–950 cm−1 and 1000–1050 cm−1) for the VPxO/SiO2 samples, especially for the VPSrO/SiO2 and VPBaO/SiO2, as compared to the VPO/SiO2. This phenomenon indicated the P-O-P and V-O-P chemical bonds (or VPO-based crystalline phases) were affected by alkaline earth metal oxide doped into VPO oxides. The VPBaO/SiO2 seems to form the (VO)2P2O7 and γ-VOPO4 with good accordance with the previous in-situ Laser Raman studies on vanadium phosphorus catalysts [52,54]. In addition, the calculated I922/I1040 values ( Table 2) of the VPO/SiO2, VPMgO/SiO2, VPCaO/SiO2, VPSrO/SiO2, and VPBaO/SiO2 samples were 1.80, 1.25, 1.07, 1.15, and 1.08, respectively, suggesting the modification of alkaline metal oxide on the VPO/SiO2 also changed the amount balance of (VO)2P2O7 / VOPO4. 3.4 XPS characterization In order to determine the surface chemical states of vanadium, phosphorus, and oxygen, XPS measurement of the prepared VPO-based oxide samples were performed. The spectra of V 2p3/2, P 2p, and O 1s are shown in Fig. 4. The multiple V 2p3/2 binding energies (BEs) of the prepared VPO-based oxide samples were in the range of 516.00 eV ∼ 520.00 eV (at about 518.20 eV), which can be deconvoluted into two separated components centered at 517.05 eV and 518.40 eV, respectively. The BE (binding energy) of V 2p3/2 around 517.05 eV and 518.40 eV can be attributed to V4+ 2p3/2 ((VO)2P2O7) and V5+ 2p3/2 (VOPO4), respectively, which is consist with the XRD and Raman results [42,52]. Moreover, the shift (also from Table 2) can be observed on V2p3/2 of VPxO/SiO2 in comparison with VPO/SiO2. According to the Fig. 4b and c, there were no significant differences in the spectra of P 2p around 134.50 eV. However, upon comparing the VPO-based oxide catalysts, the spectra of O 1 s at around 532.90 eV exhibited a similar shift trend to that of V 2p3/2. These phenomena indicated that the modification of alkaline earth metal oxide on VPO/SiO2 did not significantly impact the chemical state of phosphorus atoms, but notably influenced the V-O bonds in both (VO)2P2O7 and VOPO4. This effectively explained the Raman shift observed in (VO)2P2O7 and VOPO4 for the VPSrO/SiO2 and VPBaO/SiO2 catalysts. These results may imply the modification of alkaline earth metal oxide (especially for the SrO or BaO) improved the strong interaction between the alkaline earth metal oxide and VPO species [53]. The main surface chemical composition from XPS data for the corresponding VPO-based oxide samples are summarized in Table 2. It can be observed a surface enrichment of P element over all samples, which always occurred on both supported and unsupported VPO catalysts [38–43]. And the P element content increase after the alkaline earth metal oxide doped into VPO/SiO2, especially for the modification of SrO or BaO. This could be a good result that a slight “excess” of surface P is benefit for stabilization of the active phases ((VO)2P2O7 and VOPO4) [39,40,47,49]. The “excess” of P may lead to the formation of alkaline earth phosphate as the elements of Mg, Ca, Sr and Ba were also detected by the XPS technology, or the alkaline earth element was in the form of oxide through thermal decomposition of the corresponding alkaline metal nitrate precursor. But, this was difficult to be confirmed according to the XRD, Raman, and XPS results, because of low amount of alkaline metal oxide [18,46,47]. The total surface content of P and V followed the order of VPO/SiO2 (4.75 + 1.01 at%) <VPMgO/SiO2 (5.11 +1.13 at%) < VPCaO/SiO2 (5.62 +1.20 at%) < VPSrO/SiO2 (6.00 +1.33 at%) < VPBaO/SiO2 (6.85 +1.54 at%), indicating the doping of alkaline earth metal oxides effectively improved the dispersion and exposure of VPO species on the surface of mesoporous SiO2. Simultaneously, the surface concentrations of V4+ and V5+ species for the samples were estimated through curve-fitting analysis of the characteristic peak areas. It can be easily found that the relative amount of V4+/V5+ was significantly increased as the alkaline earth metal doped into VPO/SiO2, followed the order of VPCaO/SiO2 (0.79) > VPBaO/SiO2 (0.76) > VPMgO/SiO2 (0.69) > VPSrO/SiO2 (0.64) > VPO/SiO2 (0.25). This was in good agreement with the calculated I922/I1040 values obtained from the Raman spectra, further highlighting the impact of the alkaline earth metal oxides on VPO/SiO2-based oxide catalysts. 3.5 TEM-EDS characterization As the prominent effect of doped BaO on composition of the VPO /SiO2 based sample, the TEM-EDS characterization was further performed over the VPBaO/SiO2 to reveal the dispersion and surface composition of elements, and the image was showed in Fig. 5. It can be seen from Fig. 5a and b, the VPBaO/SiO2 had developed mesoporous structure as the N2 physical adsorption-desorption characterized. The elements of V, P, and O, as the main components, were well dispersed on the SiO2 support, with minimal detection of Si elements on the surface (Fig. 5e–h). The Ba element was also found to be well dispersed on the surface of the VPBaO/SiO2 without any aggregation (Fig. 5i). The results confirmed the BaO being successfully doped into VPO oxides and the VPO-BaO uniformly covered the surface of SiO2 with a good exposure. Fig. 5c exhibited the surface element atomic fraction of O, P, V, Ba, and Si was 69.01 %, 16.03 %, 13.73 %, 0.89 %, and 0.34 %, respectively. This is a good supplement to get more information on the surface composition of the VPBaO/SiO2. 3.6 NH3-TPD studies The effect of alkaline earth metal modification on the number & strength of the surface acid sites on VPO-based catalysts were investigated by NH3-TPD experiments, and the results are shown in Fig. 6. It can be observed from Fig. 6 that multiple NH3-TPD peaks occurred in the temperature range of 90 °C ∼ 380 °C, 85 °C ∼ 378 °C, 74 °C ∼ 368 °C, 67 °C ∼ 353 °C and 66 °C ∼ 345 °C for the VPO/SiO2, VPMgO/SiO2, VPCaO/SiO2, VPSrO/SiO2 and VPBaO/SiO2 catalysts, respectively. Generally, the NH3-TPD peaks located below 200 °C and in the range of 200 °C ∼ 400 °C were attributed to weak acid and medium strong (moderate) acid sites, respectively [19,42,50]. The results indicate that the prepared mesoporous VPO/SiO2-based oxide catalysts have weak and moderate acid sites that mainly provided by the VOPO4, because the (VO)2P2O7 was always considered as the basic sites [19,38,54]. In addition, the Py-IR (Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared) results (Fig.S2) revealed the acid sites on suface of VPBaO/SiO2 contained both Lewis and Brøsted acidity with PyB /PyL (amount of Brøsted and Lewis acid sites from the Pyridine adsorption infrared spectra) of 1.71 at 350 °C. Notably, the NH3-TPD peaks for the VPxO/SiO2 catalysts, particularly the VPSrO/SiO2 and VPBaO/SiO2, shifted to lower temperatures and had smaller peak areas compared to the VPO/SiO2. The catalysts, based on the strength of acid sites, thus can be ranked as VPO/SiO2 > VPMgO/SiO2 > VPCaO/SiO2 > VPSrO/SiO2 > VPBaO/SiO2. And, the calculated acid site content & density of samples (Table 1) followed the order of VPO/SiO2 > VPMgO/SiO2 > VPCaO/SiO2 > VPSrO/SiO2 > VPBaO/SiO2. The calculated acid site content of VPO/SiO2 obtained 215.9 μmol/gcat, higher than that (170.0–190.0 μmol/gcat) of VPxO/SiO2 catalysts, showing a good accordance with previously reported (VO)2P2O7 (149.8 μmol/gcat) and γ-VOPO4 (241.6 μmol/gcat) [39–44]. This phenomenon may be closely related with the amount balance of (VO)2P2O7 /VOPO4, as the modification of alkaline metal oxide increased the content of (VO)2P2O7 / VOPO4 especially for the SrO and BaO altered the chemical environment of VO according to the Raman and XPS results. 3.7 Catalytic activity The mesoporous SiO2 supported VPO-based oxide catalysts have been tested in the gas aldol condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde to acrylic acid at 350 °C under atmospheric pressure, and the results were showed in Fig. 7. The catalytic reaction targeted towards acrylic acid (the main detected product), and a little amount of un-shown “other products” had been identified to be the COx, acetone, Methyl acetate, and Methyl acrylate. The “other products” have not been quantitatively analyzed by the right GC-FID procedure. It can be observed from Fig. 7a that the formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity were about 61.0 % and 77.0 % over the VPO/SiO2 catalyst, with acrylic acid yield of about 47.0 %. However, the formaldehyde conversion reached about 65∼70.0 % and acrylic acid selectivity reached about 83.0∼93.0 % over the VPxO/SiO2, with acrylic acid yield of about 59.0∼66.0 %. The VPxO/SiO2 showed significantly improved catalytic performance comparing with the VPO/SiO2. Especially, the formaldehyde conversion, acrylic acid selectivity, and acrylic acid yield over the VPBaO/SiO2reached about 70.4 %, 93.0 % and 65.5 %, with an increment of about 9.2 %, 16.2 % and 18.4 % in comparison with that over the VPO/SiO2, respectively. The formation rate of acrylic acid over the VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst reached as high as about 12.5 mmol gcat −1 h−1. The VPBaO/SiO2 also showed better catalytic performance than previous supported VPO-based oxide catalysts based on the acrylic acid yield or acrylic acid formation rate, as presented in Table 3. It is known that either acid or base catalysts can catalyze the aldol condensation process, and the synergistic activation of both acid or base site were more effective to achieve the synthesis of acrylic acid, as shown in Scheme 1 [30–33,38–41]. The XRD, and Raman results revealed the VPO/SiO2 and VPxO/SiO2 were composite of (VO)2P2O7 and γ-VOPO4, which provided both few basic and abundant acidic sites for activation of formaldehyde and acetic acid, as the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD results (Fig.S1) confirmed [19,22–24,38]. This revealed the reactive components were (VO)2P2O7/γ-VOPO4 for the prepared mesoporous VPO/SiO2-based oxide catalysts, and the formation of acrylic acid achieved over the synergistic catalytic-activation of (VO)2P2O7 and γ-VOPO4. This was different with the previous studies that the co-operation of proper γ-VOPO4/δ-VOPO4 also had high catalytic performance [38–43]. Moreover, the mesoporous SiO2 with high specific surface area also played an important role in the dispersion and exposure of the reactive VPO species (VOPO4/(VO)2P2O7) to guarantee the VPO-based oxide catalyst exhibiting high catalytic performance for the gas-solid aldol condensation reaction. However, the VPxO/SiO2 shown formaldehyde conversion with about 5.0∼10.0 % higher than that over the VPO/SiO2. The catalysts, based on the yield and selectivity of acrylic acid, can be ranked as VPBaO/SiO2 > VPSrO/SiO2 > VPCaO/SiO2 > VPMgO/SiO2 > VPO/SiO2. The different catalytic activity of the VPO/SiO2-based oxide catalysts was closely related to the composition but not the porous structure of catalysts. The improved formaldehyde conversion over the VPxO/SiO2 catalysts, in comparison with the VPO/SiO2, could be attributed to the better dispersion and more exposure of reactive components (γ-VOPO4 and (VO)2P2O7). And the outstanding increment of acrylic acid selectivity over the VPxO/SiO2 was mostly benefit from the enhanced synergistic effect of (VO)2P2O7/γ-VOPO4 and alkaline earth metal oxides. Especially for the VPSrO/SiO2 and VPBaO/SiO2, the XPS and Raman results unequivocally verified the distinct surface chemical environment of VPO species compared to other samples, demonstrating a robust interaction between γ-VOPO4 and (VO)2P2O7 to enhance the synergistic catalytic activity of the VPO species. On the other hand, it can not be ignored the catalytic assisting of the alkaline earth metal oxide that also exposed on the surface of catalysts, because the BaO having enhanced the strength of basic sites on VPBaO/SiO2 though basic sites was much less than the acidic ones. The basic sites always had the catalytic assisting on acetic acid activation to promote the formation of acrylic acid [28–32]. Therefore, the high catalytic performance of VPBaO/SiO2 on formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity could be attributed to the proper balance and effective co-operation of γ-VOPO4/(VO)2P2O7 as well as the comprehensive assisting of the doped BaO, followed the previous studies as shown in Scheme 1 [17,25]. Fig. 7b exhibited the effect of amount of BaO on the catalytic performance of VPBaO/SiO2 for the aldol condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde to acrylic acid. For the VPBaO-0.07/SiO2 and VPBaO-0.23/SiO2 catalysts, the formaldehyde conversion was approximately 65.0 % and 66.0 %, while the acrylic acid selectivity was 87.4 % and 92.6 %, respectively. Both of these values were lower than that achieved over the VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst. The catalysts, based on formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity, followed the order of VPBaO/SiO2 > VPBaO-0.07/SiO2 > VPBaO-0.23/SiO2. This could be attributed to the different crystalline phase composition and content of (VO)2P2O7/VOPO4. Consequently, the VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst with an optimal amount of BaO (nBa/nv = 0.15) exhibited excellent catalytic performance for the aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to produce acrylic acid. In general, reaction temperature is a crucial thermodynamic factor that significantly impacts the conversion and selectivity of a chemical reaction. The catalytic performance of VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst was thus evaluated in the range of 330 °C ∼ 370 °C, and the results were shown in Fig. 7c. It can be seen from Fig. 7c that formaldehyde conversion increases with the reaction temperature raised from 330 °C to 370 °C, while the selectivity of acrylic acid presented an inverse altering tendency. The increasing formaldehyde conversion can be attributed to reactant molecules obtaining more energy from higher reaction temperatures, because the secondary reaction was also more likely to undergo such as a free radical polymerization of the target acrylic acid [38–43]. The decrease in acrylic acid selectivity could be related to the reduction in the total amount of acid sites and the increase in the PyB/PyL value (Py-IR in Fig.S2) of the VPBaO/SiO2. This is because the catalysis of acid sites is a crucial step in the reaction [25,26]. For the VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst, the changes on formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity led to a maximum yield of acrylic acid obtained at 350 °C, namely a suitable reaction temperature. 3.8 Catalytic stability The deactivation of catalyst is an important drawback for the gas aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to acrylic acid, which always resulted from the carbon-deposits because of the intermediates or acrylic acid can self-polymerize or polymerize with the reactants over the acid sites [22–42]. Fig. 8a showed the catalytic activity as a function of time-on-stream (TOS) over the VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst while Fig. S3 showed the catalytic activity of the VPMgO/SiO2, VPCaO/SiO2, and VPSrO/SiO2 catalysts. It can be observed the formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity gradually decreased with about 7.7∼10.8 % and 15.1∼19.5 % during the TOS from 2 h to 10 h, respectively. The yield of acrylic acid accordingly decreased about 15.4∼21.4 % as the TOS changed 2 h to 10 h. For all this, the Fig. 8b showed the formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity over the VPO/SiO2 gradually decreased with about 15.6 % and 23.1 % during the TOS from 2–10 h, respectively. The VPxO/SiO2 had more stable catalytic activity than the VPO /SiO2 catalyst. The TG results (Fig.S4) confirmed the weight of surface carbon-deposits on VPBaO/SiO2 was approximately 2.0 % lower than that on VPO /SiO2. Therefore, the experimental and TG results (Fig.S4) demonstrated the doping of BaO in VPO/SiO2 was slightly benefit for improving the catalytic stability of VPBaO/SiO2 through reducing the formation of surface carbon-deposits on acid sites. Combining with the Raman and NH3-TPD results, the doping of alkaline earth metal oxides in the VPO/SiO2 enhanced the structure stability of VPO species and reduced the amount and strength of the surface acid sites, so that the VPxO/SiO2 showed improved catalytic stability. 4 Conclusion Mesoporous alkaline earth metal oxide modified VPxO/SiO2 and VPO/SiO2 catalysts with a SBET of approximately 200 m2/g were successfully synthesized, which mainly consisted of (VO)2P2O7/γ-VOPO4 with good dispersion on SiO2. The doping of alkaline earth metal oxide into VPO/SiO2 can effectively promote the dispersion and exposure of the VPO species and adjusted the amount balance of (VO)2P2O7/γ-VOPO4 (and V4+/V5+). Particularly, the SrO and BaO altered the surface chemical environment of VPO species with strong interaction, leading to a reduction in the acidic strength and quantity of acid sites. The catalysts, based on the acidic strength and amount of acid sites, followed the order of VPO/SiO2 > VPMgO/SiO2 > VPCaO/SiO2 > VPSrO/SiO2 > VPBaO/SiO2. The VPxO/SiO2 had formaldehyde conversion of about 65.0∼70.0 %, with about 5.0∼10.0 % higher than that over the VPO/SiO2. The acrylic acid selectivity over the VPO/SiO2 and VPxO/SiO2 increased in tandem with the decreasing strength and amount of surface acid sites. Notably, the VPBaO/SiO2, optimal nBa/nv of 0.15, exhibited a formaldehyde conversion of about 70.4 %, acrylic acid selectivity of 93.0 %, and acrylic acid yield of 65.5 % at a suitable reaction temperature of 350 °C, which could be attributed to the proper amount and effective co-operation of γ-VOPO4/(VO)2P2O7 as well as the comprehensive assisting of the doped BaO. Furthermore, the VPxO/SiO2 had improved catalytic stability, benefiting from the enhanced structure stability of VPO species and reduced surface acid sites. coredata.dc:description: Aldol condensation of the syngas-methanol derivatives is an important renewable route for acrylic acid production and coal clean-efficient utilization. In this work, a series of mesoporous alkaline earth metal (x) oxide-modified VPxO/SiO2 catalysts were designed and prepared for gas-aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to acrylic acid. The doping of alkaline earth metal oxide into VPO/SiO2 effectively promoted the dispersion and exposure of the VPO species and adjusted the amount of surface (VO)2P2O7/γ-VOPO4 (V4+/V5+). Especially, the SrO and BaO obviously altered the surface chemical environment of VPO species and the strength of acid-base sites, exhibiting strong interaction with both (VO)2P2O7 and γ-VOPO4. The formaldehyde conversion and acrylic acid selectivity over the VPxO/SiO2 increased with about 5.0–10.0 % and 8.0–16.0 % comparing with the VPO/SiO2, respectively. By optimizing the doping amount of BaO and reaction temperature, the VPBaO/SiO2 catalyst achieved a formaldehyde conversion of 70.4 % and an acrylic acid yield of approximately 65.5 % (with formation rate of 12.5 mmol gcat −1 h−1). The VPxO/SiO2 catalysts also showed slightly improved catalytic stability than the VPO/SiO2.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced surface synergistic effect of alkaline earth metal oxide modification on VPO/SiO2 catalysts for gas-aldol condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde
